IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE MCGREGOR,
Respondent,
v. CASE NO.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND,
Petitioner.
OBJECTION TO MOTION TO SET
ASIDE COURT ORDERED HOLIDAY VISITATION
COMES NOW, Petitioner BRITTANY GILLILAND, by and through the undersigned
counsel of record, Barbara H. Agricola, with the law firm of Agricola Law, LLC, and files this
Objection to Motion to Set Aside Order Granting Court-Ordered Holiday Visitation. In support
thereof, Petitioner states as follows:
1. On November 5, 2025, Mother filed a Motion for Court-Ordered Holiday Visitation
which was granted by this Honorable Court on November 6, 2025 [Doc. 416];
2. On November 6, 2025, Father filed a Motion to Set Aside in regards to holiday
visitation, citing that due to reunification therapy not occurring in its entirety, that the
previously ordered visitation was not to come into effect. Further, Father states that the
weekly dinners were to replace the previously ordered visitation in the interim.
However, this did not address the matter of holiday visitation, in which no visitation
was decided. As a result, the Parties have opted to follow the holiday visitation
agreement as set out in the Parties’ Final Decree of Divorce. However, Father will not
agree as to the Minor Child A.K. The purpose of Mother’s Motion for Court Ordered
Holiday Visitation was specifically because of what is unfolding now with Father once
again blocking visitation with A.K.
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-23023-9000051.01
Objection to Motion to Set Aside
Page 1 of 4
DOCUMENT 425
3. Ironically, it is Father’s own actions that have blocked the continuation of reunification
therapy. Had all ten sessions occurred, it is likely that the Parties would have already
resumed their previously ordered visitation as set out in the Final Decree;
4. The reunification therapist has communicated on several occasions through her
counseling report, and through multitudes of emails and text correspondence between
the Parties of her policies which resulted in the therapist terminating the Parties as
clients. Despite this, Father willfully continued to ignore the counseling policies. See
email correspondence between Kelly Turner and the Parties, attached as Exhibit A;
5. In regard to family dinners, Father refuses to cooperate with Mother in regard to her
weekly schedule which is the reason for many missed dinners. This most recent dinner
on November 2, 2025, Mother respectfully asked Father to schedule dinner at 1:30pm,
which she has requested for months. Father is well aware that Mother has Sunday
church until 12:15 and has a newborn baby which has a varying feeding schedule.
Despite Father being well aware that Mother is not available until after 12:15 because
of church, and Mother pleading numerous times to adjust the meeting time between the
Parties and Minor Children, he has boldly denied her. Thus, he has deprived her of
precious bonding time with the Minor Child A.K. and Mother;
6. Furthermore, for the upcoming Sunday, on November 9, 2025, Mother has requested
that Father bring Minor Child A.K. to A.K.’s sister’s baby dedication at Mother’s
church. Father blatantly struck down this proposal and stated that the baby dedication
“doesn’t concern our two children.” Mother’s newborn is the biological sibling of the
two Minor Children in this action. It is abundantly clear by Father’s demeanor and
actions that he wishes to deprive the Minor Children and Mother of being able to foster
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-23023-9000051.01
Objection to Motion to Set Aside
Page 2 of 4
DOCUMENT 425
a relationship with their new half-sibling. This Court should note that no father would
ever in good conscience want his children to view any other family member, especially
a young baby, as “not their concern” unless it was to further drive a wedge between
Mother and the Minor Children. See Exhibit A, text correspondence between the
Parties;
7. The April 14, 2025 Order referenced by Father was clearly a temporary order filed by
this Court and not in reference to holiday visitation. Father’s assertion that Mother
should have given holiday gifts to A.K. during dinners is an irrelevant point. Mother’s
wish to exchange gifts to her children during the holidays is specifically to spend
precious family bonding time during a holiday season in which family are meant to
come together. Despite this, Father still wishes to deprive Mother of this;
8. Father’s Motion for Contempt was filed only days after this Court ordered for Minor
Child A.K.’s counseling to continue. Mother has full intention of complying with this
Court’s orders, unlike Father, and does not wish to force this Court to meddle over
minor disagreements. Mother intends to sign the required consent documentation as
soon as she is able to do so;
9. The very fact that Father would even file a motion so as to deprive Mother of only five
(5) days of visitation with the Minor Child A.K. during the holiday season is a
disgusting display of Father’s true intentions. To reiterate, Mother has been completely,
and utterly unable to exercise ANY of her visitation with the Minor Child A.K. since
this action was initiated specifically because of Father’s actions;
10. Mother respectfully requests this Honorable Court honor the Parties’ holiday visitation
agreement and uphold its order stating as such. The longer that Mother is unable to
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-23023-9000051.01
Objection to Motion to Set Aside
Page 3 of 4
DOCUMENT 425
exercise any visitation with Minor Child A.K. the more the parental alienation by
Father will worsen.
WHEREFORE, PREMISES CONSIDERED, Mother respectfully requests this
Honorable Court uphold its November 6, 2025 Order on Holiday Visitation.
Respectfully submitted on November 6, 2025.
/s/ Barbara H. Agricola (AGR004))
Attorney for Petitioner
